description1: The burritos, tortillas, and tacos with a mild spice in them can get your attendees craving for more  Host a Mexican food and drink festival and tie up with your local brewery and let the beers flow.
description2: Break the stereotypes while people always try food fests. You can give your attendees a unique experience by hosting a desserts and drinks festival with S’mores and fried twinkies along with chocolate cocktails.
description3: If you’re missing the wild wild west and you want to incorporate the Texan theme, you can host a classic BBQ and beer fest. Set up multiple barbecue stations with different meats and sauces accompanied by fresh green salads.
description4: Host a Chinese food festival in your city or neighborhood. Whether it’s the Crab Rangoon or the General Tso’s Chicken, your attendees will love to try Asian-inspired cuisine full of flavor. Incorporate soups and salads in your menu
description5: Hosting a local Oktoberfest will surely make you popular in no time. Since it’s a German folk fest, you can either choose to have German food like pretzels, pork knuckles or go with what your attendees love to eat.
description6: As the name suggests, this one’s for the health-conscious(or the ones pretending to be) event attendees. You can have grilled meats with olive oil accompanied by salads.
description7: Be it shrimps or oysters, people love seafood and will flock from any part of the state to enjoy the festival. Along with wine tasting, you’re sure to get your event sold out.
description8: Be it chaat, momos or the spicy chole kulcha, Delhiites just love their street food. The NASVI National Street Food Festival brings much-loved street delicacies from different regions of India to one place.
description9: India’s first zero-wastage food festival, Itsy Bitsy allows customers to enjoy a wider spread of dishes while reducing food wastage. At this unique festival, over 30 food stations (set up by some of Mumbai’s most popular eateries) serve bite sized portions of regular dishes.
description10: A celebration of the finest culinary experiences at formal fine dining restaurants across India, Restaurant week is currently held across Bangalore, Chennai, Delhi, Kolkata, Mumbai and Pune. It showcases specially- curated, prix fixe, three-course
description11: Food truck festivals are taking over Indian cities big time, with Delhi recently hosting its first ever food truck festival – Horn OK Please. The Bangalore Food Truck and Music Festival is being organised for the last four years while Mumbai and Ahmedabad hosted their first food truck festivals last year.
description12: With over 75 food stalls from over 12 states – from paranthas to butter chicken, halwas to ice creams, galouti kebabs to a multitude of chaat – the Great Indian Food Festival has enough variety to send you straight into a culinary coma.
description13: With over 75 food stalls from over 12 states – from paranthas to butter chicken, halwas to ice creams, galouti kebabs to a multitude of chaat – the Great Indian Food Festival has enough variety to send you straight into a culinary coma.

description1: Every year, usually in the month of February, the sandy dunes of Rajasthan comes to live with Jaisalmer Desert Festival. The festival is a unique showcase of rich and colourful folk culture.
description2: Khajuraho, famous for its erotic sculptures and aesthetic temples that date back to a period between 10th century A.D. and 11th century A.D.
description3: Bihu is a set of three Assamese Festivals falling round the year coinciding with different farming phases. The Bihu Festival is divided into Bohag Bihu, Kongali Bihu and Magh Bihu.
description4: Onam is celebrated in the beginning of the month of Chingam, the first month of the Malayalam Calendar. There are actually four days of Onam.
description5: One of the five sacred sites of the Hindu devotees, Pushkar is internationally famed for hosting the Pushkar Camel Fair, which is an annual festival.
description6: he festival is an international meet for all kite lovers. People from round the world meet up at different locations of the country like Delhi, Mumbai, Kutch, Ahmedabad and many more.
description7: The Rann Utsav or the Kutch Mahotsav is a quarter year long winter celebration in the white sandy deserts of Kutch. During the Rann utsav makeshift tents are set up in the desert for the tourists,
description8: It has its roots in the Christian tradition that was brought to Goa by the Portuguese in the early 16th century. This is the local version of the carnival which is celebrated worldwide before Mardi Gras.
description9: Losar Festival is the Indo-Tibetans’ biggest event marking the start of the Tibetan New Year. The locals come out in large numbers on the street and pray
description10: Dedicated to Lord Jagannath… the Chariot Festival in Puri, popularly known as the “Puri Rath Yatra”, witnesses a huge gathering of Hindu pilgrims and travellers from different corners of the world who seek
description11: The Hornbill festival is a yearly celebration held by Nagaland State Government in the first week of December. The weeklong celebration is a rendezvous of the Naga tribes and travellers from different corner of the world.
description12: An unusual and uncommon religious event but popular amongst the south Indians and travellers with enthusiasm for Indian culture…
description13: An unusual and uncommon religious event but popular amongst the south Indians and travellers with enthusiasm for Indian culture…

description1: One of the most popular festivals of Rajasthan, Teej is celebrated with absolute grandeur, traditional songs & dance, fair, and worship of Goddess Teej.
description2: Jaipur Elephant Festival, held every year at Jaipur Polo Ground on the day of Holi, is one of the most famous traditional festivals of Rajasthan.
description3: The Winter Festival brings together artisans and artists from different corners of the state to showcase various forms of art, handicrafts, food, and culture.
description4: The Summer Festival starts on the day of Buddha Poornima and rejoices Rajasthani folk culture & traditions for three days.
description5: This is one of the most traditional festivals in Rajasthan, where thousands and thousands of camels gather for trading.
description6: The Jodhpur RIFF is an annual festival that has been organized in Jodhpur since 2007. It aims to promote traditional folk music and arts.
description7: Popularly known as the Kapil Muni Fair, this mesmerising carnival is one of the most popular festivals in Rajasthan.
description8: To celebrate the onset of spring, Mewar Festival of Rajasthan is organised in Udaipur with grandeur and splendour.
description9: As the name suggests, this annual fair is meant primarily for cattle trading. Almost 70,000 bullocks, camels, and horses are traded.
description10: Baneshwar Festival is one of the popular tribal and cultural festivals of Rajasthan. Organised in the Baneshwar temple of Dungarpur.
description11: This religious cum cattle fair pulls travelers, cattle herders, pilgrims, and explorers from all over the country to assemble on the banks of river Chandrabhaga for a holy dip and prayer.
description12: One of the famous festivals in Rajasthan, Gangaur festival is celebrated in the honour of Goddess Parvati.
